item.title: Problem Solving: CommVault tape usage
item.description:
Introduction:

I hate dealing with tapes, pretty much every aspect of them. The tracking of them is a PITA, having to physically manage them is a PITA, dealing with tape library issues is a PITA, dealing with tape encryption is a PITA, running out of tapes is a PITA, dealing with legal hold for tapes is a PITA, and I could keep going on with the many ways that tape just sucks. What makes matters worse is when you have to deal with MORE tapes.

item.title: Backup Storage Part 5: Realization of a failure
item.description:
No one likes admitting they‚Äôre wrong, and I‚Äôm certainly no different. Being a mature person means being able to admit you‚Äôre wrong, even if it means doing it publicly, and that is what I‚Äôm about to do.

I‚Äôve been writing this series slowly over the past few months, and during that time, I‚Äôve noticed an increasing number of instances where my storage space virtual disks NTFS would go corrupt. Basically, I‚Äôd see Veeam errors writing to our repository, and when investigating, I would find files not deleting (old VBK‚Äôs). When trying to manually delete them, they would either throw some error, or they would act like they were deleted (they‚Äôd disappear), but then return only a second later. The only way to fix this (temporarily) was to do a check disk, which requires taking the disk offline. When you have a number of backup jobs going at anytime, this means something is going to crash, and it was my luck that it was always in middle of a 4TB+ VM.

item.title: Backup Storage Part 4a: Windows Storage Spaces Gotcha's
item.description: The pro and the con of a software defined storage is that its not a turn key solution. Not only do you have the power to customize your solution, you also have no choice but to design your solution. With Storage Spaces, we figured most of this stuff out before selecting it as our new backup storage solution. At the time, there was some documentation on storage spaces, but it was very much a learning process. Most ‚Äúhow to‚Äôs‚Äù were demonstrated inside labs, so I found some aspects of the documentation to be useless, but I was able to glean enough information, to at least know what to think about.

item.title: Backup Storage Part 3c: Cloud Storage
item.description: Anyone who‚Äôs heard the word ‚Äúcloud‚Äù as it pertains to technology knows its a fairly nebulous term. About the only thing people seem to grasp is that its means ‚Äúnot in my datacenter or home‚Äù. When we talk about ‚Äúcloud storage‚Äù the term is still fuzzy, but at least we know it has something to do with storage. For this post, I‚Äôm going to be writing about two specific types of storage outlined below.

item.title: Backup Storage Part 3a: Deduplication Targets
item.description:
Deduplication and backup kind of go hand in hand, so we couldn‚Äôt evaluate backup storage and not check out this segment. We had two primary goals for a deduplication appliance.

  1. Reduce racks space while enabling us to store more data. As you know in part 1, we had a lot of rack space being consumed. While we weren‚Äôt hurting for rack space in our primary DC, we were in our DR DC.
  2. We were hoping that something like a deduplication target would finally enable us to get rid of tape and replicate our data to our DR site (instead of sneakernet).

For those of you not particularly versed in deduplicated storage, there are a few things to keep in mind.
